attributed to the rise to higher air and sea fares and theatre ticket prices.The Bank of England also seems to have been caught unaware by the inflation data, having expected inflation to decline to 2.4 per cent in August.Stronger than expected inflation raises the prospect that the Bank could raise interest rates more rapidly than the additional quarter percentage point rise currently expected by the end of 2019.The Bank increased rates in August in order to head off what it saw as building inflationary pressures in the economy.“The figures won’t come as welcome news to the Bank of England added: “It does not alter our view that CPI inflation will be back at the 2 per cent&nbsptarget by this time next year.”&nbspThe largest upward contributions to inflation in August came from recreation and culture, followed by transport and clothing and footwear.&nbspThe ONS also reported that factory gate prices fell 2.9 per cent in August, down from 3.1 per cent.&nbspThe statistics story: Created with Sketch.Khan's choice of the kingdom for his first official visit, as well as comments from his finance minister, have led to speculation that Pakistan will seek a large loan from its Saudi allies to avoid another IMF bailoutClick to followThe IndependentImran Khan visits the Prophet's Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia, during his first overseas trip since taking officePakistan's new prime minister&nbspImran Khan&nbspis meeting for talks with the king of&nbspSaudi Arabia, amid speculation he&nbspwill use his first official&nbspvisit to request&nbspfinancial aid.Comments from the former cricketer's finance minister suggested Pakistan would turn to its major allies like China and Saudi Arabia, rather than rely on another bailout from the IMF.Mr Khan arrived in the kingdom on Tuesday and prayed at the Prophet's Mosque in Medina, where the doors to the&nbspProphet Muhammad’s final resting place were opened in a sign of respect for the visiting dignitaries.He then flew to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia's port city on the Red Sea, and will later dine with the Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman&nbspat a state dinner, before travelling to Abu Dhabi.&nbspMr Khan bemoaned Pakistan's financial situation in his first formal address as prime minister in August, saying&nbspthat never in Pakistan's history have we faced such difficult economic circumstances.&nbspThe country's fiscal deficit ballooned to 6.6 per cent of gross domestic product in the financial year to 30 June.He announced a series of austerity measures and raised taxes for middle and higher earners, but warned he would have to take more debt to repay our obligations to international lenders.Last month, finance minister Asad Umar said an IMF rescue was a fallback option and that the government was exploring other avenues for assistance. Mr Umar is accompanying Mr Khan on the Saudi visit.Imran Khan sheds hundreds of servants and says elite must pay taxImran Khan sworn in as Pakistan prime ministerFrom cricketing legend to Pakistan PM, the rise of Imran KhanDawn, Pakistan's largest newspaper,&nbspobserved that Prime Minister Khan’s decision to choose Saudi Arabia as the destination of his first official visit abroad has given rise to speculations about a request for aid.It would certainly not be unprecedented.&nbspSaudi Arabia loaned Pakistan $1.5bn (£1.14bn) in 2014, just six months after Islamabad's last bailout from the IMF. The money was used to strengthen Pakistan's rupee currency.In official statements, Pakistan’s foreign office said only that Mr Khan would discuss “issues of bilateral interest” with King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.Both Saudi Arabia and the UAE&nbspare major providers of&nbspjobs for Pakistanis abroad - remittance payments being a key source of foreign currency for the Pakistani treasury.Saudi Arabia in particular maintains close security ties to Pakistan, while its Muslim holy sites draw many Pakistani pilgrims each year.&nbspAdditional reporting by agenciesEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Trump hails deal, which could see North Korea invite international observers for dismantling of&nbspnuclear and missile sites, as 'very exciting'Click to followThe IndependentNorth and South Korean leaders sign joint agreement on denuclearisation in 'leap forward' for peaceAt a joint press conference after the signing, South Korea's Moon Jae-in&nbspsaid North Korea had agreed to&nbsppermanently shut down all of its nuclear and missile testing facilities, in the presence of international experts, as long as the US takes reciprocal measures.The two sides agreed that Mr Kim would visit Seoul, in what would be a first for a North Korean leader. And the two leaders agreed a number of wide-ranging measures designed to increase cooperation and reduce the risk of armed clashes on the border.&nbspMr Kim said the pair had agreed to turn the Korean peninsula into a land of peace without nuclear weapons and nuclear threats.The US had called for concrete developments regarding denuclearisation&nbspduring Mr Moon's three-day visit to Pyongyang, and Donald Trump suggested the joint agreement did not disappoint.Very exciting! was his response to the news on Twitter.&nbspKim Jong-un has agreed to allow nuclear inspections, subject to final negotiations, and to permanently dismantle a test site and launch pad in the presence of international experts. In the meantime there will be no Rocket or Nuclear testing, Mr Trump said.Mr Kim has promised the complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula before, after which US officials said they suspected work continued to be carried out at North Korea's nuclear sites in secret.The most practical details in Mr Kim and Mr Moon's agreement came with regards to inter-Korean projects and relations. The pair agreed to launch a joint Korean bid for the 2032 Summer Olympics, as well as pooling resources for major sporting events before then.Haley accuses Russia of ‘cheating’ to help North Korea avoid sanctionsKim Jong-un requests second Trump meeting in letter, White House says Nuclear missiles absent from North Korea's 70th anniversary paradeThey agreed to establish a joint military committee&nbspto evaluate how to reduce tensions and maintain communication to defuse crises and prevent accidental clashes.And according to a joint statement signed by the countries' defence chiefs, the two agreed to establish buffer zones along their land and sea borders to prevent accidental clashes. They will withdraw 11 guard posts from the Demilitarised Zone by December and establish a no-fly zone above the military demarcation line that bisects the two Koreas, applying to planes, helicopters and drones.&nbspWith the main business of the day over, North Korea was expected to hold a huge mass games spectacle in the evening, with Mr Moon as the special guest.&nbspThe North had put the games, which feature tens of thousands of performers dancing and flipping placards in unison to create giant mosaics and slogans, on a back burner for the past several years, but revived them for this month's celebrations of its 70th founding anniversary. story: Created with Sketch.Moscow's rhetoric moves from 'irresponsible actions' to 'tragic circumstances'Click to followThe IndependentVladimir Putin dialled down the rhetoric yesterday, after an initially furious responseRussia and Israel step back from brink after Syria downs military planeVladimir Putin has looked to downplay the potential of a serious diplomatic rift between the Kremlin and the Knesset following the downing of a Russian military plane late on Monday evening.&nbspFifteen Russian servicemen died after an Il-20 reconnaissance plane was struck down in a friendly fire incident involving Syrian S-200 anti aircraft defences that had targeted&nbspIsraeli jets.Speaking on Tuesday afternoon, Mr Putin said the incident was the result of a “tragic chain of accidental events”. His measured comments erged from an earlier, furious response.&nbspIn the early morning, the Russian Defence Ministry intimated the plane had been hit&nbspby Israeli or French fire. Later, spokesmen changed the story, accepting the plane had been shot down by the Syrians. But&nbspthey ratcheted up the diplomatic fury.&nbspIn quick succession, Moscow said Russians had died as a result of Israel’s “irresponsible actions.” It blamed the Israeli command for giving just a minute’s advance warning of its air strikes. It accused their pilots of using the larger Il-20 plane as cover during missions. It summoned the Israeli ambassador to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Smolenskaya Square and it gave Israel’s defence minister a public dressing-down.&nbsp“The actions of the Israeli defence ministry do not reflect the spirit of the Russian-Israeli partnership,” Sergei Shoigu, the&nbspRussian minister of defence&nbsptold Israeli opposite number, Avigdor Lieberman. “We reserve the right to take further steps.”&nbspThe fierce response suggested a difficult period ahead for Russian-Israeli relations.&nbspUntil that point, cooperation between the two countries had been close. In May, Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu attended Victory Day celebrations in Moscow in&nbspa symbolic gesture at the height of the Kremlin’s international isolation. Russia also seemed to accept Israel’s strategic interests in the region.&nbsp“There was a lot of trust between the two sides,” said Yuri Barmin, an expert at the Russian International Affairs Council on Tuesday. “It was seriously undermined today.”The incident brought back memories of November 2015, when a Turkish fighter shot down a Russian Su-24 jet that had violated Turkish airspace. Russia retaliated with sanctions and seven months of hostile relations&nbspensued.Moscow is trying to be friends with everyone –&nbspwith Assad, Israel, Turkey, the Kurds. That, of course, is the source of the problem&nbspSome of Russia’s more excitable politicians suggested&nbspMoscow could respond&nbspby supplying&nbspDamascus with more advanced C-300 anti aircraft systems – a kind that would prove more problematic for Israeli planners.&nbsp“Russia simply can’t let this drop,” said Franz Klintsevich, member of the Russian senate’s Defence Committee.&nbspBut the likelihood of a serious military response from Russia was always low. Even if it wanted to, Russia does not have the capacity to close Syrian air space to Israeli jets.More fundamentally, it was never going to wade into the undeclared war between Israel and Iran.&nbsp“Russia will not stand in the way of Israeli operations to stop Iranian expansion, knowing how existential they are seen in Jerusalem,” said Jonathan Spyer, research fellow at the Jerusalem Institute of Strategic Studies. “Moscow is trying to be friends with everyone – with Assad, Israel, Turkey, the Kurds.&nbspThat, of course, is the source of the problem.”&nbspRussia-Turkey deal over buffer zone in Idlib met with scepticismUN warns of ‘worst humanitarian disaster’ of 21st century in SyriaRussia ‘resumes airstrikes’ on Syria’s Idlib despite Trump warningIn his afternoon comments, Mr Putin urged&nbspagainst a direct comparison to the Turkish Su-24 incident. That was an intentional strike he said this was “an accident.”&nbspThe president’s unexpectedly&nbspmild response brought into question how much of the initial show of anger against Israel was real – and how much a tactic of&nbspdeflection&nbspfrom a military that had made mistakes.“Russia understood it has only itself to blame for not making sure the Syrians had the right friend-or-foe identification systems,” said Vladimir Frolov, a security expert and former Kremlin advisor.&nbspThere were&nbspother, more obvious questions to be asked. How was it that communication with Syrian allies broke down? How could an anti aircraft system mistake a large reconnaissance plane for a fighter jet?Part of the answer lay in the technology, suggested Justin Bronk, a research fellow at RUSI, an international defence and security think tank based in London.&nbspDesigned in the Soviet Union in the 1950s, the Syrian S-200 surface to air missile unit is not a failproof system, he said. Without newer fire control and radar systems, it would have had difficulty differentiating between the two planes.A lax approach to firing the missiles may also have played a role.&nbsp“During recent attacks, the Syrians have tried to give their public an impression of having effective defences,” said Mr Bronk. “So they have fired missiles blindly – on simple ballistic trajectories, or at least with very weak firing solutions. That may have contributed.”In a statement released on Twitter, the Israeli Defence Forces said the blame for the incident lay “firmly with the Syrian regime,” which had fired missiles “indiscriminately” in response to Israeli&nbspairstrikes.&nbspRussia understood it has only itself to blame for not making sure the Syrians had the right friend-or-foe identification systems&nbspBut the statement also expressed “sorrow for the death of the aircrew members of the Russian plane”.&nbspThat show of humility may have given Mr Putin enough to move on.&nbsp“The operational dynamic may change slightly, but the politics can’t change,” added Mr Barmin. “Russian doesn’t have so many allies that it can throw one of them&nbspunder the&nbspbus.”&nbspEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Dementia risk could be a postcode lottery depending on air pollution levels (Image: )Researchers from the University of London, Imperial College and King&rsquos College London used anonymous patient health records from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink, which collects data from GP practices.They focused on 131,000 patients aged 50 to 79 in 2004, who had not been diagnosed with dementia, registered at 75 general practices within the M25 area.The health of the patients was tracked for an average of seven years, until they were diagnosed with dementia, died or left their GP practice.Between 2005 and 2013, 2181 patients (1.7 per cent) were diagnosed with dementia, 39 per cent of whom had Alzheimer&rsquos disease and 29 per cent of whom had vascular dementia.                Dementia: Are men or women more likely to develop Alzheimer&rsquos disease?                Dementia: Is it possible to slow down symptoms?Between 2005 and 2013, 2181 patients (1.7 per cent) were diagnosed with dementia (Image:  STOCK)These diagnoses were found to be linked to ambient levels of nitrogen dioxide and the microscopic particles PM2.5, based on estimates taken near the homes of patients in 2004.Those living in areas with the top fifth of nitrogen dioxide levels had a 40 per cent higher risk of being diagnosed with dementia than those living in areas with the lowest.A similar increase was seen with levels of PM2.5 in the research findings, published in the journal BMJ Open.The links could not be explained by factors known to influence the development of the condition but were more consistent for Alzheimer&rsquos disease than vascular dementia.                Could a 53p-a-day pill help improve your memory?Further work is urgently needed to explore recent findings linking air pollution and dementia (Image:  STOCK)The diseases that cause dementia can begin in the brain up to 20 years before symptoms start to show (Image:  STOCK)The authors said: &ldquoFurther work is urgently needed to confirm and understand better recent findings linking air pollution to dementia. Our results suggest both regional and urban background pollutants may be as important as near-traffic pollutants.&ldquoThe cause of these neurodegenerative diseases is still largely unknown and may be multifactorial. While toxicants from air pollution have several plausible pathways to reach the brain, how and when they may influence neurodegeneration remains speculative.Alzheimer&rsquos Research UK described the study as a &ldquogrowing area of research, but chief scientific officer Dr David Reynolds added: &ldquoWhile the researchers tried to account for factors like wealth, heart disease and other potential explanations for differences in dementia rates across the capital, it is difficult to rule out other explanations for the findings.&ldquoThe diseases that cause dementia can begin in the brain up to 20 years before symptoms start to show.&ldquoWe don&rsquot know where people in this study lived in the two decades before their dementia diagnosis, so we have to be cautious about how we interpret these results.Separate research, presented on Sunday at the European Respiratory Society International Congress in Paris, found children who have green spaces near their homes have fewer respiratory problems such as asthma later in life.Those who are exposed to air pollution are more likely to suffer.

story: Tory minister James Brokenshire signalled the UK is unwilling to change its Brexit strategy further and expects Brussels to evolve its position before the November talk deadline.Mr Brokenshire spoke out in support of Theresa May's Chequers blueprint, saying it would deliver on the main demands of Leave voters &ndash including gaining control back of laws and borders.Speaking to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, the Tory MP said: We have clearly evolved our position and it is now for the EU to evolve its position.I think the Chequers deal sets out a deliverable, workable plan. Verhofstadt says EU citizens are not 'so stupid' to vote to leave EU                Brexit SNUB: Tusk to give May just 10 minutes to warn bloc of NO DEALEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier dismissed the Brexit white paper claiming the European Union would not accept to sign into an agreement threatening the unity of the single market.But the Prime Minister has remained firm on her position, with Mr Brokenshire saying he remains positive Mrs May will be able to see her plan through.He continued: This is a negotiation but we very clearly put on the table something that is deliverable, that is workable, that takes back control of our borders, our laws and the issue of not sending large sums of money to the EU. Now we wait to see how the EU responds but I remain positive and confident.Based on the feedback we have received from other EU member states on how we can take this forward and therefore look with confidence on a deal that secures the best interests of our country and we, therefore, have that sense of where our country is moving in that very very positive sense.Brexit news: May has been facing increasing pressure from Brexiteers and the EU to change her plans (Image: BBC&bullEPTV)Despite criticism of her Brexit plan agreed by the Cabinet at Chequers from both Brexiteer and pro-Brussels Tories, the Prime Minister insisted she was confident that a majority of MPs will back her hoped-for final deal in the Commons.Speaking exclusively to the , Mrs May said: &ldquoI&rsquom confident that when can get a good deal and when people come to look at that at the final endpoint in these negotiations, I hope people will reflect on the fact that we did give a vote to the people, we said to the public: &lsquoIt&rsquos your choice&rsquo. It&rsquos our job to deliver on that.The Prime Minister will meet with other EU leaders in Salzburg on Wednesday evening to review the progress of the negotiations less than two months away from the final deadline.&nbspMr Barnier has revealed on Tuesday the EU is &ldquoready to improve its Irish border proposal &ndash in an apparent climb down from Brussels' previous hardline stance on the issue.Speaking following the General Affairs Council on Article 50, the French negotiator claimed October will be the &ldquomoment of truth for Brexit negotiations adding: &ldquoWe are now on the home straight.

title: Brexit news Guglielmo Picchi Theresa May Salzburg summit UK EU withdrawal latest
story: The Italian undersecretary of State for Foreign Affairs warned Theresa May should make sure to make herself heard or risk being ignored before a Brexit deal is struck.Echoing the advice Italian deputy PM Matteo Salvini gave to Mrs May back in July &ndash urging her to impose yourself to stop the European Union from&nbsp swindling you &ndash Mr Picchi called on the UK to speak out.Speaking to the Today programme, the Italian MP said: It&rsquos actually what happened to our Government on migration.It&rsquos the position that unfortunately some governments have to take in the EU Council and the EU in general that either you speak very loud or the EU will ignore you.                Brexit breakthrough: EU 'READY to improve' Irish border plan &ndash Barnier                &lsquoCome to Stoke&rsquo - CHALLENGE issued to anti-Brexit Lord on NewsnightThe Italian politician warned of the risks to trade a no deal would have on both the UK and the EU, encouraging both sides to secure a mutually beneficial agreement for the future.Mr Picchi also called on Brussels to show more willingness to meet Britain halfway and discuss the latest Brexit blueprint Mrs May put forward in July.He continued: We believe the British proposal, the Chequers proposal, is a good one. We would like to see more willingness on the EU side.We should not be allowed to have a blind Brexit. We should have a clear path ahead, so the two-years transition period could be something necessary.Brexit news: Picchi advised May to speak loud or risk being ignored by the EU (Image: OSCE&bullBBC)He added: I always remember the EU is the UK&rsquos biggest trading partner so it&rsquos in their interest, not of the Government but of the people, to have a clear way ahead.Mrs May will on Wednesday night appeal directly to EU leaders in a bid to force EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier to climb down on demands.The Prime Minister will call for a compromise over talks, particularly with the Irish border issue, during a crunch summit in the Austrian city of Salzburg.EU chief Brexit broker Michel Barnier hinted he was ready to make the first move in concluding gruelling talks on the Irish backstop that have plagued Brexit negotiations since the June 2016 referendum.Speaking last night he claimed the bloc is &ldquoready to improve its Irish border proposal before warning the October EU summit will be the &ldquomoment of truth for Brexit negotiations.He said: &ldquoWe are now on the home straight.

title: God is a woman Christ Christianity what does God look like Ann Widdecombe
story: The heated exchange was sparked by Rae Duke&rsquos comments, a religion and ethics commentator, who believes God should not be referred to as either a man or woman.The call comes after a YouGov survey found almost half of 18-24-year-old Christians believe God is male, with one in three over-65s believing the same. Only one percent of respondents believed God was female.When asked by ITV&rsquos Good Morning Britain host Piers Morgan why people are being told it is &ldquooffensive to call God a man, Ms Widdecombe said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think it&rsquos remotely offensive. In fact, I have never heard such nonsense throughout the entire New Testament. Christ is a he and Christ refers to God as the father.&ldquoA father, even in this day and age, is a he. But what really worries me is the sheer superficiality of this. Because the whole objection to calling God he is apparently that it puts people off Christianity.                Eye of GOD: Strange apparition appears in sky                Life after death: Woman drawn to light wasn&rsquot afraid&ldquoIf you are not going to be won over by the message of redemption and forgiveness, you&rsquore not going to be won over by somebody saying &lsquooh look God is a she&rsquo. Come on.The religious commentator hit back and said Ms Widdecombe should look at the message of Christ. She said: &ldquoIf you think about St Paul who spread the message&nbspof&nbspChristianity, he said that there is neither male nor female for all one in Christ.When grilled by Piers Morgan about why Christ was referred to as &ldquothe father, Ms Duke said: &ldquoBecause at the time that had cultural relevance. If you think about the prodigal son, it wouldn&rsquot have worked for that parable to have been a mother because a mother would never have owned property to have given it away as&nbspan&nbspinheritance&nbspto her child.&ldquoHe had to use the father to represent God. That doesn&rsquot mean God is a male. God is above and beyond any gender. It&rsquos impossible for human language to ever encapsulate what God is.Ann Widdecombe hit back at claims God should be referred to as a  (Image: ITV)Mr Morgan asked whether God is &ldquogender fluid, to which the religious expert said was a &ldquoridiculous claim, adding: &ldquoGod can be neither female nor male. I think, says everybody.Ms Widdecombe fired back at the expert&rsquos claim and said: &ldquoThroughout the entire New Testament, Christ refers to God the father. The nonsense that that was only a convention of his time and that somehow people wouldn&rsquot have accepted it if he had referred to a woman.She added: &ldquoAnd what is more, all this debate is really very stupid because it&rsquos got nothing to do with the central message of Christianity.The former Tory MP said people think of God in &ldquodifferent ways, adding: &ldquoIt might be a human form. It could be whatever it is. I think people cope in different ways with the whole concept of God and until we see him face to face we won&rsquot know.&ldquoBut what we do know is that he is consistently throughout all the Christianity, throughout 2000 years, been a he. Christ said &lsquoGod the father&rsquo. I don&rsquot actually think it matters very much.The Church of England&rsquos first female diocesan bishop and other leading Church figures have also said that God should not be referred to as a &ldquohe.The Bishop of Gloucester, the Rt Rev Rachel Treweek said: &ldquoI don&rsquot want young girls or young boys to hear us constantly refer to God as &lsquohe&rsquo.She warned it is important to be &ldquomindful of our language so as to avoid alienating non-Christians from the Church.Ms Treweek told the Sunday : &ldquoFor me, particularly in a bigger context, in all things, whether it&rsquos that you go to a website and you see pictures of all-white people, or whether you go to a website and see the use of &lsquohe&rsquo when we could use God, all of those things are giving subconscious messages to people.&ldquoI am very hot about saying we can always look at what we are communicating.Bishop Treweek became the first female bishop to sit in the house of Lords in 2015 and famously sent back the initial version of her writ of summons because it referred to her as a &ldquoright reverend father in God.But the Rev Sally Hitchener, Anglican chaplain at Brunel University, said it is &ldquoheretical to say God is only male.Rev Hitchener said: &ldquoNo academic theologian in the UK would objectively say that God is male, and yet that is common parlance in a lot of the Church and definitely the message coming across in lots of the media communications that we&rsquore sending out there.

title: feel super campaign 40 things
story: Bumping into a friend gives us a lift (Image: )The smell of a cake baking, bumping into a friend and remembering there are freshly washed sheets on the bed are other moments that give us a lift.A baby's smile is enough to put a grin on one in four Britons' faces while listening to uplifting music brings cheer to three in 10.One in five of us turn to chocolate to lift our mood, but a third believe true joy comes from doing a good deed for others.The study was carried out by OnePoll for Superdrug and Procter &amp Gamble, whose #Feel-Super campaign raises money for the Marie Curie cancer charity.                Time for tea? Eight reasons to put the kettle onThe Saturdays singer Frankie Bridge alongside radio host and former JLS star DF Marvin Humes are launching the campaign's first charity song, The #FeelSuper Song, which celebrates the little everyday things that make a difference.Hannah Drew, for P&ampG, said: By giving people a special 'feel super moment' through this song, we are hoping to inspire even more involvement and drive further donations to raise as much as possible for the vital services Marie Curie provides.The study found that more than a third of those who have had someone close to them suffer a terminal illness found happiness in playing their favourite music playlist.Half of these respondents said a great song makes them feel super because it reminds them of a happy memory.One in five of us turn to chocolate to lift our mood (Image: )Annie Wade, a Marie Curie nurse who features on The #Feel-Super Song, said: The song makes us all recognise how important it is to celebrate the little moments in life. It is something I know first-hand as a Marie Curie nurse.We provide palliative care as well as much-needed physical and emotional support to families across the country 24 hours a day, seven days a week.But so often it really is the small things that make the biggest difference.Making a cup of tea for a family member in the middle of night, playing a patient one of their favourite songs or just sitting with them so that they know someone is there with them.These are just a few of the things I do to try to give much-needed comfort and support to patients and their loved ones.Mr Humes added: It is all about the people that make a difference - the Marie Curie nurses, volunteers and staff.The song embodies what we are trying to do here - celebrate the people that are on the ground, making a difference every day, and inspire the rest of us to do our bit to support them.                Modern life, it appears, is set up to make us feel anxious                Turn your home into a calming sanctuaryLIFE'S SIMPLE PLEASURES1 A hug2 Sun shining3 Freshly laundered sheets4 Hearing someone say they love you5 Reading a good book6 Getting a compliment7 Listening to uplifting music8 Solving a problem9 Being under a blanket when it's cold and wet outside10 Seeing a close friend after a long whileA hug tops the list (Image: )11 A smiling baby12 Your favourite song coming on the radio13 Having someone supportive to talk to14 A hot shower15 A cup of tea16 Watching your favourite TV showfilm with someone17 A proper cup of coffee18 Starting a new series of your favourite TV show19 Eating a big bar of chocolate20 A haircutThe smell of a cake baking and a cup of tea are also on the list (Image: )21 Dining at your favourite restaurant22 Smell of cake being baked23 A home-cooked meal after being away24 Seeing others having fun25 Bumping into a friend26 Freshly washed hair27 Old people holding hands28 A social event you secretly didn't want to attend being cancelled29 Going to an exercise classdoing exercise30 Retail therapyOld people holding hands is among the top 40  (Image: )31 Tucking into a lush slice of sponge cake32 Listening to a favourite dance tune33 Someone helping with the cleaning34 Wearing your favourite outfit35 Being offered a biscuit or favourite treat36 Being told you don't have to cook tonight37 Your favourite artist releasing new music38 Hearing a new joke39 A gin and tonic40 Catching green lights all the way to work

title: BBC Weather forecast latest London Met Office UK Storm Ali today
story: Storm Ali &ndash British forecasters&rsquo first named storm of the season &ndash threatens &ldquoinjuries and danger to life due to flying debris, according to the Met Office.&nbspBBC Weather forecaster Matt Taylor warned that Britons should &ldquobatten down the hatches day today in preparation for Storm Ali.Mr Taylor said: &ldquoIt&rsquos going to be quite a stormy day for some of you.&ldquoMet Office amber warning has been extended to part of north east England now to take us through there this morning and into the afternoon.                Storm Ali tracker map: Where will Storm Ali bring DANGEROUS winds?                What are the school closures for tomorrow in Northern Ireland?&ldquoNorthern Ireland and southern eastern Scotland and&nbspnorth east&nbspEngland where amber warnings are in force &ndash a potential for damage and also some travel disruption.&ldquoLet me just show you where the exact weather disruptions after. It goes all the way up towards Aberdeen &ndash&nbspstronger to the winds over towards Northern Ireland and extending for mid-morning it hits parts of central southern Scotland and it is in the amber warning area where we could see winds in excess of 70mph.&ldquoStorm Ali is responsible. Its first proper name storm of the season &ndash bringing with it some rain too.&ldquoBut the strongest winds not just across the north. It&rsquos going to be windy across the border. Just the example across some of the wind gusts &ndash widespread gales.BBC Weather forecast: UK warned to batten down the hatches (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquo50 to 60mph gusts even across central and southern parts of England and Wales. But it is across Northern Ireland and central and southern Scotland where the worst of those winds will be.&ldquoAnd coupled with that this morning &ndash heavy rain at the moment in Northern Ireland spreading in with those stronger winds through the morning and into parts of central and western Scotland as well.It will be a dry start of the rest of the country on Wednesday. Mr Taylor said: We will see some spots of rain and drizzle in the short term. East Anglia in the south east. Brightening up here to sunny spells. Even though the wind will be picking up.Showers then push in across England and Wales. But brightens up a little bit for Northern Ireland and southern Scotland as we go through the day.The BBC weather forecaster said much of Scotland will feel &ldquomuch much cooler than it has done over the past week.The forecaster added: &ldquoTemperatures still into the 20s of course tempered by that wind.But he warned that into the early hours of Thursday the rain will return again across parts of Wales and the south west, towards the Midlands. Mr Taylor said: &ldquoThis is where a wetter zone will be. Some heavy thundery showers in the north and west of Scotland. But in between those we will see some clearer skies.The rain will get heavier into Thursday afternoon and push its way into north west England.London and the south east will not escape the heavy rainfall, with Friday likely to bring with it some heavy downpours.BBC weather forecast: Met Office issues amber weather warning (Image: BBC)Mr Taylor said: &ldquoEven across southern parts of England you could see a spell of heavy rain through Thursday night and into Friday morning. Strong winds through the night as well.The Met Office extended its weather warning to an amber alert for gusts of up to 75 mph for northern parts of England, Scotland and Northern Ireland between 8am on Wednesday to 6pm as Storm Ali moves in.The Met Office statement reads: &ldquoStorm Ali will bring a spell of very strong winds to Northern Ireland from early on Wednesday morning before these strong winds spread to far northwest England and central and southern Scotland by late morning. Strong winds will be accompanied by heavy squally showers.&ldquoSome areas, especially high ground and coastal regions, including within the Central Belt, could see gusts of 80mph at times. Winds will ease from the west through the afternoon.

title: chequers deal brexit theresa may cabinet
story: The Prime Minister, however, faces substantial opposition from within the Conservative Party to the plan. Heres what you need to know.After a marathon session of talks at Chequers on July 6, Theresa May managed to secure a Brexit plan which will be assessed by the EU.Her Brexit plan will see the UK remains closely tied to the Brussels.It also includes the creation of a new UK-EU free trade area for goods, with a common rulebook.This rulebook could limit the UKs ability to strike trade deals with countries such as the US, for whom securing market access for American farmers would be a big prize.Mrs May has agreed to an amendment that would stop Britain being tied to Europes customs union after we quit the EU.In dramatic scenes in the House of Commons on July 17 2018, Mrs May managed to see off a damaging attempt, winning by just six votes.Mrs May was then defeated on a separate amendment to her flagship Trade Bill, which will require her to seek continued UK participation in the EUs system for regulation of medicines after Brexit.Now her Cabinet is required to ensure that the UK can continue to participate in the regulatory network operated by the European Medicines Agency.Mrs May hopes to get an agreement hammered out at a series of summits with EU leaders this autumn, and bring it back to Parliament for approval.A deal on the UKs withdrawal agreement was expected to be agreed in time for the summit in October, along with a statement from both sides on the future relationship.However, a number of senior figures have said this deadline may slide into November.Once a dead has been agreed, MPs will be asked to approve it.In a Panorama interview in September 2018 she said MPs had a simple choice between her Chequers plan or no deal.She told the BBC current affairs programme: I think that the alternative to that [the Chequers plan] will be not having a deal.The former Foreign Secretary claimed Mrs Mays disastrous plans for the Irish border would leave Britain at a loss.Boris Johnson said the European Unions fallback position for the Irish border would mean Northern Ireland was annexed by Brussels.Opposition to the plan in the Conservative Party centres around the European Research Group of hard - Brexit supporting MPs led by Jacob Rees - Mogg.His voice had been among the loudest voicing their objection to the plan and he urged MPs “chuck Chequers”.Up to 80 Tory MPs are prepared to vote against Theresa Mays Chequers plan, Steve Baker, a former Brexit minister and ERG backer has warned.A group of about 50 Tory MPs have met to discuss how and when they could force her out of her job, the BBC reported.Also voicing his opposition to the Chequers deal has been former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.He said Theresas Mays had wrapped a suicide vest around the British constitution and handed the detonator to Brussels.Along with former Brexit secretary David Davis and Mr Johnson resigned in protest following the Chequers meeting.Several other MPs also quit their ministerial posts over the issue, including Steve Baker, Maria Caulfield, Ben Bradley and Robert Courts.The party will vote down any Brexit deal brought back from Brussels by Theresa May, according to shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry.The Corbyn ally said the party will oppose it to try to force an election by Christmas.Speaking to the FT she said a deal which meets her party’s tests was “not going to happen”, and therefore the Prime Minister would be forced to quit.Without the support of the opposition party, it would need just a handful of Tory rebels to vote against her to see it defeated.Theresa Mays initial plans brought her on side with those Conservatives who favour a soft Brexit.The Prime Minister has also been seeking grassroots Tory support for the plan.Among those voicing support for the Prime Minister has been Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who was a prominent member of the Leave campaign.He said he was confident that the Prime Minister will go into the Conservative Party conference and beyond, securing a good Brexit deal for Britain and continuing to ensure the country enjoys good economic growth and we take advantage of Brexit.A plan may have been cooked up but it still needs to get past the EU — and the continent’s leaders are showing no sign of compromise.Angela Merkel is already rubbishing our proposal.The Napoleonic Emmanuel Macron thinks he’s a political messiah, and he’d rather see us punished than give up on his federalist promised land.And Michel Barnier’s dangled “concessions” amount to a demand for total UK capitulation.With that level of zeal and stubbornness, it’s no wonder we voted in our millions to leave.We must now go to Brussels with an offer that guarantees control of our borders and sign our own trade deals.But we mustn’t for a second think that they’ll just say yes to it, nor can the PM let them fatally weaken it.It is galling that ministers have spent more time fighting between themselves than preparing for a “no deal” exit.But it isn’t too late.New technology can ensure that Whitehall and our borders are ready for a clean break, which considering the strength of our economy and our companies is nothing to be scared of.The PM has dumped many of her earlier Brexit slogans. But she should remember one in particular now.No deal really is better than a bad deal, and we must still prepare for it.

title: inside the tiny island of mirrors where 100 pairs of twins live one in every three families and no one knows why
story: Thats because Alabat, home to just 15,000 people, is home to more than 100 pairs of twins.Right now, 78 are non-identical and 22, including four-month-olds Gian and John, look exactly the same.Those two lads are the youngest while Eudosia and Antonia, 86, are the oldest, MailOnline reports.And just to trick people into thinking there might actually be a glitch in the Matrix, many dress the same.Antonia, who married when she was 19, said her husband had a clever way of telling them apart.She said: In the initial days my husband would often mistake Eudosia for me.There were some embarrassing moments when my husband made amorous overtures to my sister thinking that it was me.I then showed him that I have a mole on my nose while my sister does not have one. That solved the problem.The number of twins on Alabat may even have gone up in the last few years.In 2013, Transterra Media reported around 60 of them on the island.At the time, the mayor said four per cent of the islands 12,039 residents were twins.He and his we were shocked to find so many on the island when they migrated there in the 1980s.A historic study found a 182 per cent increase in multiple pregnancies in 35-year-old women between 1996 to 2006 due to the use of fertility drugs.But this could not have influenced Alabat, a remote island which did not have access to the medication.No scientic studies have been carried out to find out why there is such a high ratio of twins on the island.

title: karren brady column alcohol vanity good health
story: One day, butter is the enemy. The next it’s sugar. Then carbs. A few weeks later, sugar is back on the naughty step.It’s the same with alcohol. Until recently, a glass of wine a day kept heart attacks at bay. Last month, we learned that NO amount of alcohol is safe. Then this week our new goal, apparently, should be two teetotal days a week.It’s hard to keep up — and no wonder many people ignore all the reports. Who wants to be told what to do by a bunch of scientists who can’t make up their mind?But the latest news from Public Health England should give us all pause for thought, because British women now have some of the lowest le expectancies in Europe.Girls born in the UK today can expect to die three-and-a-half years earlier than girls in Spain, the country that comes out top in this report. The reasons? Rising levels of obesity and poor cancer survival rates.British women also fare badly when it comes to premature deaths — defined as before 75.Many are caused by cancer, heart disease, stroke and type 2 diabetes, which are linked to smoking, alcohol and junk food.France, home of Michelin star chefs, is also way down on the list. And so is Italy.My supporting evidence is that I live with an Italian, who would be more likely to attend a funeral in a jester’s hat than eat a bag of crisps.Clearly, we all need to take a leaf out of the same book.The prevailing wisdom is that it’s more expensive to eat healthily. But that’s not true.A recent report from the Institute of Economic Affairs shows it’s possible to have your five-a-day for less than 30p — and a nutritious,  plain, diet can be bought for less than £1 a day.Meanwhile, the cheapest adult meal in McDonald’s is about £4.50, for which you could make a fresh vegetable curry for the whole family.So it’s not about money. Why, then, do us British women fare so badly?I wonder  we are so daunted by images of women airbrushed to perfection, in adverts and on social media, we feel we can’t compete. So we give up, eating what we like and not exercising.Because keeping really fit takes serious work.The latest insight into this is from movie star Mark Wahlberg who shared his daily schedule this week.He’s in bed by 7.30pm then up at 2.30am for the first of his two daily workouts. His fitness schedule only allows for two hours’ “work” a day — and thus it becomes clear his job is, in fact, his physique.Since most of us spend at least ten hours a day working and commuting, you can see why it’s often easier not to bother.But it’s not just our health that’s in peril. It’s also that of our children, for whom we are the primary role models.Not about vanity, but good healthI have evidence in the form of my best friend, who is a marathon-running exercise junkie — as is her daughter.I, on the other hand, although not proud of this fact, do no exercise — and my daughter doesn’t enjoy it as much as her friends.Getting fit and losing weight can feel impossible.But look at Labour deputy leader Tom Watson, who this week announced that he has lost 7st and put his Type 2 diabetes in remission, which is pretty inspiring.So let’s choose to make this bad news story into a positive and use it as inspiration for change.Let’s aim for two booze-free days a week.And maybe ditch the biscuits for a bit and make some other small, sustainable changes that will leave us able to go for a brisk walk without fearing a heart attack.This is not about vanity, it’s about good health. Because the alternative is sobering.When it started off 18 years ago it was innovative and exciting TV. But now it’s degenerated into a hotbed of fame-hungry wannabes pitted against each other and behaving horribly as a result.Now it’s been axed. About time, too.I BELIEVE in people’s right to protest – of course – against political views they disagree with. But, Ian Bone, the protestor who assailed Jacob Rees-Mogg and his children on their own doorstep has crossed a line.“Your daddy is a horrible man,” Mr Bone told Mr Rees-Mogg’s bewildered-looking children, who will likely be traumatised by the incident – and will certainly not forget.MPs are already putting a lot on the line to serve their country. Many endure threats of violence or even death – and just look at what happened to Jo Cox.Yes, it’s fine to disagree with politicians and to protest. But taking it out on children and trying to make them feel bad about their father is bullying behaviour that is wholly unacceptable.Speaking to LBC afterwards, Mr Bone, who is 71, said that he saw no problem with involving children in his protest.But despite being happy to bring Mr Rees-Mogg’s offspring into the argument, he refused to speak about his own five children, and repeatedly refused to answer  he would have been happy for them to be treated in the same way.Talk about hypocritical.EVERYONE praised as progress the BBC’s “solution” to the inequality on comedy panel shows, which has been to ensure there is at least one woman on every show.But then we hear from Sandi Toksvig that their contributions are often edited out.The QI host told the Radio Times: “There are panel shows that struggle to get women on, and that’s because . . . in the edit they are often seen just laughing at the boys and not saying anything at all, even though I know for a fact in the recording they were clever.”Turns out that turning up and being funny isn’t quite enough,  you are a woman, to be given the same air time as men. How annoying.MY Woman of the Week award goes to Carol Vorderman who, at 57, is clearly in her absolute element and loving le.She looks healthy and oozes confidence, especially in these skin-tight jeans.She told ITV’s Lorraine this week she’s happy being single and is not looking for a “keeper” or another intense relationship.In fact, she said she “couldn’t think of anything worse”.How refreshing. And what a great role model she is for women in their fties and beyond.WATCHING the video of a homeless man being sprayed with paint in Middlesbrough made my blood boil.The poor man – who was found dead just days later in a cemetery – is filmed sat against a wall, covered in paint, as a man brags: “This is how we dealwith the beggars on the street.”This disregard for another human being’s dignity is obscene and the yob should be made to volunteer helping homeless people.Until he sees that dehumanising this man who had hit troubled times was the lowest of the low.DID you see Madonna’s daughter, 21-year old Lourdes hitting the runway for the Gypsy Sport Spring Summer 2019 showcase at New York Fashion Week?It’s so dispiriting, isn’t it, that the headline news about her appearance, which could have focused on so many dferent things – her incredible confidence, for one – was that . . . she hadn’t shaved her legs, top.I guess true equality will have been achieved when a woman’s hairy calves go unmentioned and are seen as neither here nor there.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony blair nick clegg and john major meet with european leaders in secret plot to keep britain in the eu
story: The two former Prime Ministers and former Deputy Prime Minister have meet with senior politicians in Europe in bid to persuade them to stop the UK leaving the European Union.They have also been working with other prominent Remainers including Peter Mandelson.The mission was begun by Mr Clegg independently but he has taken on the role of informal co-ordinator of the group,  reported.In recent weeks Clegg he met Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister and the foreign policy team of the French president, Emmanuel Macron.He has also met senior German politicians including Bundestag president Wolfgang Schäuble and Peter Altmeier, the German economics minister.Last week Blair met senior politicians in Germany and Austria and Italy’s new interior minister, Matteo Salvini as well as the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier.Both have said they would be looking for Article 50 to be extended so a deal can be struck to remain in the EU that addresses concerns about immigration.“The aim of the visits is to persuade EU leaders that British politics has made the option of remaining inside the EU viable,” said Mr Clegg.“It is a question of pressing them to keep open the extension of the article 50 process beyond the March deadline to give UK negotiators more time including to prepare legislation on a people’s vote.“We cannot just turn the clock back to just before the 2016 referendum.“There would have to be some changes of freedom of movement - we cannot just put Humpty Dumpty back together again.”Mr Blair, who met Barnier on 18 July, said the main focus of his meetings was discuss a new common approach to immigration in the UK and EU.“You cannot deal with this Brexit issue unless you deal with the questions of immigration and the anxieties that gave rise to it,” he said.At a meeting on Wednesday night in Salzburg, Austria, Theresa May will have a chance to try to persuade other EU leaders to adopt her Chequers plan to for the future relationship with Brussels.

title: jacob rees mogg column theresa may brexit
story: The Prime Minister will head to the continent on Thursday to visit Salzburg — like Bath, a world heritage city — to discuss her Brexit or Chequers proposals with other leaders of European governments.To date the EU has been officially dismissive of the main elements of Chequers, the complex customs arrangements and continued use of European Rules to secure access to the single market.Michel Barnier, who led the negotiations for the EU, has been clear that the EU cannot accept this position.The UK must either be in the Single Market with all that goes with it — including free movement — or it may have a free trade deal instead.In a sense, he is the keeper of the Orlamme for the EU.Historically, this was a sacred banner carried into battle for the kings of France when no prisoners were to be taken.The heads of government may be more conciliatory and keener to help a fellow leader, not least as most of them face their own domestic dficulties.It is also the usual form for the EU to make a deal.It protests that it is strictly a rules-based organisation to maximise its negotiating strength but then, like an honest costermonger, makes the necessary trade.At the same time the British Government seems desperate to agree something on almost any terms.Chequers rubbed out the Prime Minister’s red lines to leave the UK “half in, half out” subject to EU regulations in crucial areas of the economy, and to the European Court of Justice.The vassal has been put in chains.This desperation means it will be important to watch carefully what comes out of Salzburg.Any deal will be hailed initially as a triumph because of the hostile comments made not only by Mr Barnier but, in his recent state of the Union speech, by Jean-Claude Juncker.Overcoming these obstacles will be portrayed as a triumph for British diplomacy.Those who hope that Brexit will continue to mean Brexit will need to stay awake.The first item to watch out for is money. There is no legal obligation to pay anything at all.This has been established by the House of Lords and no credible authority has questioned their Lordships.If we pay £40billon we must get something clear in , not just wishy-washy promises.Taxpayers would be outraged  it were otherwise.Any agreement on immigration must be examined with great care.We will doubtless be told that free movement has ended but, as Shakespeare wrote, “what’s in a name? that which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet”.There ought to be no preferential terms for new arrivals from the EU above those offered to other nations and no access to state benefits.There must be a clear dferentiation in their rights after we have left and admission must be subject to a work permit scheme focused on skilled rather than unskilled labour.The solution to the Irish question is a further area where Brexiteers must be alert. Last week the European Research Group, which I chair, produced a paper explaining how it could be answered on the EU’s terms.Obviously the UK could simply say that there will be no physical infrastructure at the border but  instead we examine what the EU does on its other borders, and see  those precedents could be followed, then no reasonable person would think a “hard” border were necessary.So far the inevitable attacks on our reports have been mere rudery. No one has found fault with facts.If Ireland were used to justy the major concessions the Government is giving then we would know the deal is a bad one based on a false premise.It would be better than any other which the EU has so far agreed but Ireland is supposed to make it impossible.The issue has been used by those who are fearful of leaving the EU to keep us bound by its rules and regulations.Inevitably these complex machinations have led to some gossip about the leadership.These stories come from all wings of the Party with pro-Europeans such as Tom Tugendhat and George Freeman suggesting it is time to move to a new generationHowever, it is worth remembering the Prime Minister’s virtues.She is determined, thorough and dutul, and in my view duty is an heroic virtue.This gives her great strength and without a clear Parliamentary majority it is not obvious that anyone else could steer the negations to a conclusion.Pitt the Younger was hailed as the pilot who weathered the storm. Changing the pilot would not affect the weather.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels chequers corbyn number 10
story: Her task is to sell her botched Chequers deal on Brexit to 27 EU leaders who think it is rubbish.Her half-in, half-out formula has been trashed by Tories, Labour and even by Brussels.Nobody likes it. Nobody wants it.But this self-described “bloody dficult woman” believes she alone can ram it through.Either she knows something nobody else does . . . or her fabled “polished turd” is about to hit the fan.On tonight’s BBC’s Panorama, Mrs May spells out the formula she thinks propelled her to the top: “You bide your time and you are bloody dficult when it really matters.”Others fear a dferent characteristic has defined her political career, especially as Home Secretary.“She is mulishly stubborn,” says a former ally.“Once she digs her heels in, nothing can sht her — right or wrong.”They fear she will stick defiantly to her half-baked plan until she runs out of road and is forced to choose between an EU fudge or defeat in the House of Commons.The Chequers deal is flawed by the fantasy we can follow an EU rule book on free trade and regulation while reserving the right to duck and e.Outside Cabinet, Tories on all sides — Brexiteers and Remainers — insist it is unworkable.“It fails to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade,” writes ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith.“We would be out of Europe yet still run by Europe.”EU negotiator Michel Barnier fears it endangers the whole EU project, which is already threatened by tensions over mass immigration, the Euro and jobless school leavers.Special treatment for the UK would instantly trigger demands from other member states for their own tailor-made deals, unravelling the drive for ever-closer union.Mrs May claims there is no alternative to Chequers.But there has to be — and Britain is already working on it.Despite Chancellor Phil Hammond’s blundering interference, preparations for a clean break are in train, covering everything from free trade to the vexed border with Northern Ireland.It may be pitched as a last-ditch option, only to be deployed in an emergency.But since Chequers is universally seen as a non-starter, free trade automatically becomes the only viable plan on the UK table.New Brexit minister, karate black belt and rising star Dominic Raab, is making this vividly clear in Brussels.He alarmed Downing Street by threatening to withhold the EU’s £40billion ransom  they push us too far.And he has told Barnier to do his own dirty work and impose a border in the Irish Sea  he dares.This is music to the ears of Tory MPs who desperately yearn to see some fighting spirit.They hope against hope Mrs May secretly has a cunning plan, ready to roll out at the right moment as she suggests, calling Barnier’s bluff.But there is another red card on the table, face up and flashing danger to our EU neighbours.Do they want to humiliate the PM to the point where she is defeated in Parliament and pushed into a second catastrophic election?EU leaders can read the polls which put Labour in front.They will also be horried to see ex-Tory vice-chairman Jeffrey Archer unhelpfully saying he would vote for Corbyn  he were a Northerner.And we should all be alarmed by David Cameron’s Goldman Sachs-trained Treasury minister, Jim O’Neill, saying: “I find myself struggling to be that scared by the prospect of a Corbyn government.”The EC has enough on its plate with the growing explosion of anti-Brussels populism across Europe. The last thing it wants any time soon is a hard-left Labour government led by lelong EU-haters Jeremy Corbyn and Marxist Chancellor John McDonnell.It might be the one bargaining chip that makes Michel Barnier blink first.For a Bank of England governor, his forecast of a 35 per cent crash in house prices verged on the hysterical.Project Fear has lost the power to shock, but it won’t stop trying.Aircraft will not fall from the sky, the Channel Tunnel will stay open, NHS patients will not starve or die from lack of NHS drugs.Not only have Carney’s nightmare scenarios of slump and mass unemployment proved false, the reverse has happened.Young workers are flocking to the UK for jobs. Wages are rising. Growth is strong.Now we see French companies such as Chanel stampeding to invest billions here. Unilever, one of the biggest firms on the planet, is reviewing rash plans to move to Holland . . .All despite Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weather forecast uk today storm helene
story: It followed off the back of the remnants of Hurricane Helene and is pummelling the UK with extremely strong gales. Heres the latest weather update.Large parts of northern England, Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland will be battered by strong gales.Heavy rain will also accompany the wind.Elsewhere it will be windy too, with sunny spells either side of a band of showery rain, moving southeastwards.The Met Office said: Storm Ali will bring a spell of very strong winds to Northern Ireland from on Wednesday morning, these moving across the far far north of England and across central and southern Scotland by late morning.Strong winds will be accompanied by heavy and squally showers.Some areas, perhaps most likely the northwest of Northern Ireland, parts of southern Scotland and the far northeast of England as well as exposed coasts and high ground, could see gusts of 80 mph at times.Winds will ease from the west through the afternoon.But temperatures will remain reasonably high for this time of year.It could reach the mid-20s in the South East on Tuesday while further north temperatures will hover around mid-to-high teens.Tonight the strongest winds will ease but it will remain very windy in the north with gales and blustery showers.There will be clear spells further south before heavy rain reaches Wales, central and northern England towards dawn tomorrow.Storm Ali is battering Northern areas with 85mph winds and heavy rain today.Here an Amber weather warning is in place as gales pose a threat-to-le.A woman in Ireland died after her caravan was blown off a clf while debris and fallen trees closed roads.Power outages were expected and airports and ferries suffered major disruption.Meanwhile, Yellow wind warnings were issued across the whole of England and Wales for the coming days as Alis influence continues.The windy weather is expected to move further south with 65mph gusts expected to bring disruption on Thursday and Friday.Wales and the North West will also be pummelled by heavy rain on Thursday — enough to merit a Met Office Yellow warning.And the windy wearher will continue for most of England and Wales on Friday, with wind speeds reaching a bracing 50mph.Next week will begin with yet more windy weather across all of England and Wales.A Yellow weather warning is in place for both Sunday and MondayThe Met Office said there is a chance of disruptive winds developing with parts of England and Wales currently looking most at risk next week.The Met Office warns the public and emergency responders of severe or hazardous weather which has the potential to cause danger to le or widespread disruption through the National Severe Weather Warning Service.The Met Office issues warnings for thunderstorms, rain, snow, wind, fog and ice.These warnings are given a colour depending on a combination of the likelihood of the event happening and the impact the conditions may have.There are a number of ways you can find out whether your area is at risk from flooding.The Environment Agency, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and Natural Resources Wales update their warnings 24 hours a day via the Floodline number.The highest 24-hours of rainfall in England occurred in Cumbria on December 5, 2015.According to the Met Office 341.4mm of rain fell at Honister Pass, Cumbria, in 24-hours, a new UK rainfall record, while at Thirlmere 405mm also set a new record for two consecutive rain-days.Sloy Main Adit in Scotland experienced 238mm on January 17, 1974.And on November 11, 1929, Lluest Wen Reservoir in Wales was flooded with 211mm of rainfall.The record for Northern Ireland was in 1968 at Tollymore Forest, County Down, which saw 159mm.

title: leo mckinstry opinion immigration multiculturalism debate
story: Mass immigration is transforming the size and the nature of our population.Between 2001 and 2016, the number of people living in the UK increased by 6.6million to 65.7million. And the influx continues.Latest statistics show the number of migrants who settled here in the year to March 2018 was 614,000, equal to a city bigger than Bristol. Net migration was around 270,000.Yet the revolution has been imposed by the ruling elite without any consent. No British citizen was ever asked to vote for this upheaval. No major party ever sought a mandate to open our doors.This helps to explain why the British public has such profound distrust in MPs on the question of immigration, as revealed in a major new opinion survey published this week.In the biggest consultation of its kind, involving 20,000 interviews, just one in six people showed any faith in the Government to tackle migration, while only 13 per cent felt that politicians are “open and honest” about the issue.These findings are not the result of bigotry or prejudice. Britons have been remarkably tolerant in the face of change.Indeed, that shines through the survey, which discovered that 65 per cent of people believe migrants bring valuable skills to the economy and the public sector. Similarly, 59 per cent think that ersity benefits our national culture.But British decency has been exploited by the political class to implement its agenda, with the result that disillusion is now widespread.People are rightly fed up with politicians who indulge in denial and deceit about the reality of mass immigration.A classic example was the phoney claim from the last Labour Government that, when the former communist countries of eastern Europe joined the EU in 2004, just 13,000 of their citizens would come to the UK. In fact, more than a million did.Even worse has been the attempt, particularly by the Left, to suppress open discussion by hurling accusations of racism against critics of mass immigration.A climate of censorship now prevails where public figures are expected to parrot the fashionable orthodoxy, and ordinary citizens are afraid to voice their concerns.Yet the anxieties of the public are all too genuine. Immigration has imposed more strain on our civic infrastructure, reflected in the shortage of affordable housing, the never-ending NHS crisis, the growth in the welfare burden and dficulties for parents in finding school places for kids.The import of cheap foreign labour has meant lower wages and job insecurity. Just as disturbing is the erosion of solidarity because of this upheaval.Social cohesion cannot exist without real integration, as the public recognised in the survey.The majority of respondents, 88 per cent, agreed with the idea that “migrants should learn English” and 85 per cent believe that migrants “should share our values”.But the multicultural ideology, which has long been the creed of the state, works in the opposite direction.It encourages migrants to cling to the practices and languages of their native lands, fuelling ision. As does the institutionalised acceptance of sharia law, which arguably offers more protection to men than women, undermining the traditional concept that we are all equal before the law.The consequences of multi-culturalism are seen at their most corrosive in the failure by the state to tackle serious crimes perpetrated by ethnic minorities, such as the organised abuse of girls by mainly Asian gangs in places like Rotherham and Derby.More concerned to uphold the illusion of cultural ersity’s success than to protect victims of crime, the police and other authorities indulged in a cover-up. It was only exposure of the abuse by journalists that finally forced them to act.That mix of official dishonesty and paralysis only undermines our society. There is a lesson for us from Europe, where the political order is threatened by growing public anger over immigration.In 2010, German Chancellor Angela Merkel declared that “this multi-cultural approach has failed.” But she did nothing to reverse the policy. Instead, she opened the door even wider, especially in 2015 when she allowed in more than a million migrants.The crime that followed has led to public outcry.Britain has always been renowned for its avoidance of extremism. But we will avoid the same fate only  the state adopts a new approach on immigration, including more political honesty, tighter border controls and an emphasis on British values.That is not racist. As the public knows, it is a recipe for greater harmony.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit gaffes sun says opinion
story: His boss, the Prime Minister, insists we will thrive whether there’s a Brexit deal or not. The EU has to know that she is unafraid to walk away  need be.What does her blundering Remainer Chancellor do?Volunteers his own apocalyptic warning about No Deal reversing our progress since the 2008 crash.Mr Hammond has leapt on the IMF’s latest doom-laden predictions and swallowed them whole, despite its abysmal forecasting record over the financial crisis, austerity and the Brexit vote.The Chancellor has already hampered vital No Deal preparations, undermined the new Brexit Secretary and only last week suggested delaying our departure.Now, at a stroke, he has sabotaged our negotiating hand and boosted the EU’s.It is a measure of the weakness of Mrs May’s position after the loss of her majority that Mr Hammond is still in his job.REMEMBER Brussels mocking the Brexiteers’ idea of high-tech customs checks to solve the Irish border problem?The technology didn’t exist, they said. It was a “fantasy island unicorn model”.Triumphant Remoaners piled in. It proved Brexiteers were clueless, they chirped. And Downing Street then ­produced its convoluted alternative.Except the EU, in the form of Michel Barnier, now believes in the fantasy island unicorn model too. The trouble being it wants it used between Britain and Northern Ireland instead of Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.And the DUP, whom Theresa May needs for her survival, won’t wear that. Nor should they, since it ides the UK.Funny though, isn’t it, how Brussels move the goalposts when it suits them? They have negotiated in bad faith all along.TOO many politicians are in denial about the soaring cost of the NHS and social care. So we applaud Health Secretary Matt Hancock’s imaginative plan to sort the latter.The new lelong insurance system he is considering, compulsory for all workers unless they take a risk and opt out, looks a practical idea to fund part or all of an OAP’s care costs.It would give them peace of mind that they wouldn’t have to spend their savings or the proceeds from their home.Maybe it will work. Maybe not. Regardless, it is to Mr Hancock’s credit that he is starting a grown-up conversation at last over future funding of health.For too long progress has been stymied by the Left using any change to the NHS as a political weapon.But the structure of a health service designed in 1948 now needs a radical rethink.It is time reality dawned.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
